title: Two conducting spheres set - outer charge

content.description: Two concentric spherical conducting shells and four labeled points <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math>, <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi> </math>, <math alttext="T" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></math>, and <math alttext="U" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi></math> are shown in the figure. The outer shell has a net charge of <math alttext="negative 20 nanocoulombs" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>−</mo><mn>20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>nC</mtext></mstyle></math>. The inner shell has a net charge of <math alttext="positive 10 nanocoulombs" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>nC</mtext></mstyle></math>.
content.question: What is the charge on the outer surface of the outer shell?

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
